Leaving humanism behind: Notes towards indifference
Confronted with those who neglect to recognize themselves in our festivals of negation, we offer neither sympathy nor dialogue but only our derision.
Confronted with those who neglect to recognize themselves in our festivals of negation, we offer neither sympathy nor dialogue but only our derision. The compulsive humanism proposed to us is like a bad joke, and instead of laughter we respond with social war. In the articulation of zones of offensive opacity, we destroy those who would have us give up the singular joy of crisis for the misery of activism. To those who deride the immanent joy in a burning dumpster or a moment of friendship, we propose nothing less than to reject their homogenous mobilization, by any means necessary.
Every burning dumpster is a refusal to negotiate, a blow against the temporality of liberalism, a recognition of the radical teleology inherent in the articulation of becomings. It is necessary to commence without illusions; not to dream of new ways to make demands, but to make manifest the subterranean encounters in the heart of each burning dumpster. We must destroy all passivityâ€”without illusions. Our need to riot is less the realization of a project than the realization of a state of exception.
What's needed is not humanism, and even far less normalization, but a putting-into-practice of immanent crisis, a rejection in all forms of the temporality of banality. This is a call to social war, not an insistence on humanism.
